posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

>>Can't stomp a rebellion a few steps from it's capital
Literally what are you referring to here? If you mean the Easter Rising, it was decisively stomped after Britain intercepted gun shipments to Ireland from Germany. If you mean the General Strike of 1926, "stomping" protesters is rarely going to get you reelected.
>Empire collapses after "winning" a world war
This is a fair statement; involvement in WW2 at least was very badly thought out and resulted in financial ruin for the empire. However, I would point out that the same thing happened to France after 16 years of counterinsurgency in Indochina and Algeria. Really, America and the Soviet Union were the only winners in WW2. Central and Western Europe became second-rate players until the present day.
>Was britain a paper tiger?
idk what you mean by that in this context. The fact that Britain was able to deploy troops to anywhere in the world (as well as still being able to fight the Falklands War forty years after it stopped being a world power) would seem to show that Britain was very formidable during its imperial period. Plenty of other countries would've taken Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, Egypt, Canada, the Thirteen Colonies (before Revolution) and Britain's other colonies if Britain hadn't been able to claim and defend them. Saying that any world power is a "paper tiger" seems kinda pointless, because it was clearly the most powerful among its peers. So, unless the entire human race was a "paper tiger" for that period, then no.

>>14621290
The UK could easily have suppressed the IRA if they'd actually started treating it like a military conflict rather than a policing matter. The question was: to what end?

Bernard Montgomery, a major who served in Ireland, wrote of the issue:

>My own view is that to win a war of this sort, you must be ruthless. Oliver Cromwell, or the Germans, would have settled it in a very short time. Nowadays public opinion precludes such methods, the nation would never allow it, and the politicians would lose their jobs if they sanctioned it. That being so, I consider that Lloyd George was right in what he did, if we had gone on we could probably have squashed the rebellion as a temporary measure, but it would have broken out again like an ulcer the moment we removed the troops. I think the rebels would probably [have] refused battles, and hidden their arms etc. until we had gone.

It was a particularly pointless war from the UK's viewpoint given that they had already been on the cusp of giving Ireland Home Rule just before the outbreak of WW1. An often overlooked fact is that Ireland didn't actually gain independence after the rather inaccurately named War of Independence - they remained a part of the British Empire with the King as their head of state. So really the settlement the British got after the war was barely more than what they had been going to give the Irish anyway. It wasn't until the 1940s that Ireland severed the last constitutional ties with the UK.

There was also the issue that, contrary to what a lot of people seem to think, Irish people could vote in UK parliamentary elections. Keeping Ireland in the union would have led to a sizeable Sinn Fein block in the British parliament, which would have been inconvenient for all concerned.

And all this aggravation would have been for a region that was economically worthless to the UK.

>>14621225
Imagine being this obsessed with geopolitics. The real explanation is a lot simpler: Japan developed much faster after World War II than China did, never experienced communism and so had a much stronger consumer culture than China. Cold War politics may have had a very minor role in making mainland Chinese cultural output less attractive to Westerners than Japanese cultural output, but this factor was relatively small.

The much more significant factor was that mainland China just didn't produce as much stuff to consoom (Taiwan and Hong Kong did produce more, which is why they achieved some success in exporting their culture both to other parts of Asia and also to the West).

Why did Japan in particular have such overwhelming success in exporting its culture? Probably because it has so many different successful cultural industries, all of which have fanatical fanbases at home. Animation. Comic books. Movies. Novels. Art. Cuisine. Not all of these cultural exports are equally successful in every market, but there are so many of them that at least a few are guaranteed to succeed in each.

>>14612154
They heavily influenced many Germanic peoples, but many Huns were already mixed by the time they entered the Germanic orbit. Specifically they had a huge component of Scythians sarmatians and proto Slavs. Germanic peoples such as the gepids, goths, rugi, heruli, and others were known for their skill with cavalry. In fact the romans called these people Scythian rather than German because Germans weren’t known to ride their horses into battle, rather dismount and form an infantry line before charging. These cavalry tactics were originally from eastern Iranian peoples but became reinforced by hunnic overlordship as for them the horse and horse based warfare was the most important thing in life. Even some “western” Germanic peoples like the longobards and Thuringians were introduced to these concepts, probably during the hunnic phase, as they became great cavalry peoples. Specifically we know the Longobards had either mixed hunnic kings, or kings in complete subjection to the Huns and their culture penetrated to the entire longobard society. The kings Lethuc, aldihoc, and godehoc have what Capo calls “Turkic ceremonial names” with the translations representing possibly Germanic or hunnic prefixes with the Turkic suffix -juks being represented in Latin as -hoc/huc. This dynasty, which was intrusive to longobard society as it was not descended from the original kings, was responsible for the greatest part of their migration from north east of the Elbe down into Pannonia, most likely influenced by their nomadic overlords and new taste for horsemanship.

posts.com:
I never see Chile’s role talked about during the falklands war

In the late 70’s Argentina and Chile nearly went to war over the border conflict around the ownership of the lands and thus waters of the straights of Magellan. The only thing that stopped it was a last minute intervention from the Pope. They then had mediation between the countries (mediated by the British as the third party ironically) and most of the islets were awarded to Chile. Argentina immediately repudiated the mediation and began preparing for war again.

Argentina was pretty open about the fact they planned to invade the southern cone owned by Chile once they’d conquered the falklands from the British and had peace with them. They simply didn’t expect the British would actually come out in full force to retake and defend the falklands, rather that they’d negotiate from a position of strength and the British would give them the islands for some concessions elsewhere. Or take the loss since it would be so costly to take them back for little gain.

During the Falklands war, Argentina’s military and equipment was much bigger and more modern than Chile’s, and they’d have likely won (at significant cost considering how defensible the terrain was though). This was due to chile having been embargoed for human rights abuses while Argentina got away with it much longer and could import from other major manufacturers like Germany.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Chile had pre-emptively has their navy airing the straits expecting the attack, as well as manning the isles with soldiers

Chile, not wanting Argentina to win against he British and then come after them. Was one of the only lite American countries to not support Argentina’s claim

Indeed, Chile even provided crucial intelligence information to Britain to try and give them an edge without provoking the ire of Argentina or other Latin American countries by giving material help.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Chileans knew if it came to an actual war. There was little chance they could actually win against Argentina. The manpower and equipment gap was too large between them at that point.

The Chilean strategy was thus to instead make a show of force along the border and the disputed area. The idea being that Argentina would have to reconsider attacking Chile because although victory was extremely likely. The cost would be massive and very bloody for the Argentinian military and its soldiers. The terrain was easily defensible, Chileans had mined areas they believed the Argentinians would attempt to cross. They also planted dynamite in crossings around the mountains.

A consequence of this rise in tensions is that Argentina put a TON of its best troops on the Chilean border. Either in preparation to attack them, or as a precaution if Chile attacked first.

As a result a lot of the troops sent to take the falklands were fresh inexperienced troops as it was seen as an easy task. The falklands before the was a small unimportant island with only 68 soldiers on it as a token force.

In retrospect, if Argentina had sent a ton of well trained troops to invade the falklands and then defend it, they’d have fared a lot better. Britain would likely have been more amenable to negotiations after the islands had been seized for a few years. And Britain could never just start bombing it because the island was full of civilians next to the enemy soldiers

>In January of 1973—the same month that the Rolling Stones were banned from touring Japan due to prior drug convictions, the same month that a band called Kiss played its first gig in Queens, and the same month that a young New Jerseyan named Bruce Springsteen released his debut album on Columbia Records—Harper’s magazine published an essay by future Pulitzer Prize winner Margo Jefferson titled “Ripping Off Black Music.” The piece was partly a broad historical overview of white appropriations of black musical forms, from blackface minstrel pioneer T.D. Rice through the current day, and partly a more personal lament over what Jefferson, a black critic, had come to see as an endless cycle of cultural plunder. The article’s most striking moment arrived in its penultimate paragraph:

>The night Jimi died I dreamed this was the latest step in a plot being designed to eliminate blacks from rock music so that it may be recorded in history as a creation of whites. Future generations, my dream ran, will be taught that while rock may have had its beginnings among blacks, it had its true flowering among whites. The best black artists will thus be studied as remarkable primitives who unconsciously foreshadowed future developments.

>>14617392

Bluegrass, country, blues, rock and roll, all of them come from the central blend of Scots-Irish and West African, the Irish fiddle meeting the banjo, a combination unique to the South. Bluegrass is a blend of old school Appalachian folk or old time string music emphasising the off-beat (pretty directly Scottish and Irish, Scottish bagpipes and ole-time fiddlin) and West African rhythms and instrumentation (clawhammer banjo). Country music is much the same in origin throughout the American west, a blend of Irish, Scottish and English folk traditions with West African rhythms, repetitions and instrumentation, with some threads being influenced by Latin music like Mexican, norteño, mariachi and tejano. Bohemian polka has also had an influence in places like Texas. Western swing is like country-jazz, or jazz that became country. In the 1920s, the 'hillbilly' music scene around Atlanta saw the introduction of the Hawaiian steel guitar and ukelele, and that's when country music truly came into existence as a genre distinct from bluegrass, blues and other American folk music. You also had jug bands and, in Louisiana, French-influenced Cajun and Creole music which led to things like zydeco and had an influence in New Orleans, the birthplace of jazz.
You throw in the developments of Negro sprituals, gospel music, cakewalk/ragtime, New Orleans big band music, and you can piece together most of the history of American music.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14617762

Jazz is originally African American, and employed Black New Orleans and Cajun sounds, inspired by spirituals and hymns, also with the West African cross-rhythms and call-and-response style of work songs and field hollers, preserving the 'traditional sub-Saharan African harmony' of African drumming, but in other polyphonic styles after the Black Codes outlawed drumming by African slaves. There was also a Cuban habanera/contradanza influence. The big innovation in jazz was the jazz scale, which draws from common scales of Western European classical music (diatonic, whole-tone, octatonic, melodic minor modes), but allowing for the interpretation, repetition and improvisation central to jazz as a genre. Jazz was initially an urban phenomenon in the South - Dixieland jazz in New Orleans in the 1910s - but when the blues scale developed in the rural Deep South, it entered jazz and introduced the out-of-key "blue note" to an existing scale, notably the flat fifth addition to the minor pentatonic scale, and jazz was never the same again. New Orleans jazz travelled north to Chicago and New York with the First Great Migration in the 1910s, generation on generation. Cakewalk and ragtime developed on the way in places like St Louis, influenced by jazz, but when it reached New York it got sucked up into theatre music and Yiddish musical styles, which is the origin of Tin Pan Alley. After a generation, big band music was formed, and swing became the most popular American music genre for about 15 years (Louis Armstrong, Billie Holiday, Ella Fitzgerald).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14617789

Blues had been growing in the Deep South since the 19th century, arguably since the end of the Civil War. Initially, blues was literally just spirituals and slave songs, and many of the old blues standards are written in this style and come directly from those traditions. The lines are often sung following a pattern closer to rhythmic talk than to a melody, which is seen as something reflected in Igbo music. The four-beats-per-measure of the blues has been associated with the melodies of the Bambara people, and to a lesser degree, the Soninke people and Wolof people, but not as much of the Mandinka people. The original country blues coagulated in the Mississippi delta as Delta blues, which was heavily influenced by folk music. This is when country and blues were essentially bonded, and blues had a great effect on the birth of bluegrass. Robert Johnson was a master of the Delta blues, and was part of the transition from uncommercial to commercial blues, which saw it explode in popularity. As the Second Great Migration (starting in the 40s) saw Blacks coming out the Deep South, bringing the country blues to the Northern cities where jazz and swing were already dominating, the new synthesis and the popularisation of blues scales and chord progressions like the 12-bar-blues (most famous chord progression in popular music) began the birth of early rock and roll. One split off before rock and roll was 'rhythm and blues' and doo wop, which was more swing and big band oriented. Chuck Berry then took the aggressive guitar sound from electric blues and made rock and roll what it would eventually be.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14617793

Skiffle music was basically British blues, inspired by a combination of the blues and old Victorian music hall. When rock and roll and the new commercial genre of 'rhythm and blues' hit the Mersey and its skiffle bands in the 1950s, beat music was born, from which The Beatles emerged. Rhythm and blues and rock and roll spread across the Western world, influencing Caribbean music genres like calypso and nyabinghi which led to rocksteady, reggae and dub.
The rest of popular American music - r'n'b, soul, funk, hip hop, punk, metal - all came from descendants of the synthesis between the New Orleans jazz that spread to the Northern cities with the First Great Migration, the old-school American rural folk music like bluegrass, and the Southern Delta blues that exploded in popularity immediately following WW2.

Basically, without Africans, American music probably wouldn't have had A) the banjo, B) blues scale, or C) jazz polyphonic harmonies. These are all things that seem to have originated from different forms of West African music carried over by slaves. American music would still probably be incredibly unique and diverse, with many other influences, but a large portion would be fundamentally different. Perhaps there would be even more folk influence, in the style of blue grass, or more Latin and French influence (although Latin music is very African-influenced). It's also a high chance that Western art music/classical music and its scales and modes would still be very popular amongst the upper classes. If you want to imagine 20th century popular music without African Americans, imagine a more folk-like bluegrass without a banjo and without a blues scale, instead working on a traditional European classical scale like diatonic, whole-tone, etc. There also may have been more indigenous influence than in real life.

Europe already had pop music before American jazz became popular in Europe, mostly produced in Germany and Austria. Schlager music, or arguably, the earlier operetta. These were inspired by European folk music and waltzes, were written to be short, catchy, could be played in a few (or even just one) instrument, easy to sing along, had simple, usually sentimental lyrics etc.

So without the African influence, American music would likely copy this trend, thanks mainly to German immigrants. Maybe Anglo-Irish influences would be mixed in as well.

The music industry as we know it would still develop because recording would still be invented and someone would figure out that you could make a lot of money selling music records. So American music would be just as commercialized as it is in reality. Later on, electric instruments would be invented too. Maybe the electric guitar wouldn't be as common, instead electric violins or harmoniums would be more popular.

Blues, rock and roll, rap would not exists, but some electronic music genres like techno would likely still develop because they are not as directly influenced by African-American music as blues or rock and roll is.

As people get bored with these musical styles, maybe they would discover some "exotic" culture's music which would become popular globally, possibly Middle-Eastern music.

>>14618672

The violin predates Irish and Scottish fiddling by hundreds of years, but it was Scots-Irish immigrants in the 17th and 18th centuries who brought the to Appalachian mountains. These immigrants were usually dissenters - Ulster Scot Presbyterians who left due to the Confederate Wars, 17th and 18th century famines, the Penal Laws which disadvantaged non-Anglicans, or the absentee landlordism of the Anglo Protestant Ascendancy. Bluegrass fiddling is descended from Ulster/Donegal and Highland/Borders fiddling styles.
Although a fiddle is basically the same as a violin, fiddle music as a style means that there will be specific construction differences between a fiddle and a classical violin - fiddles will have flattened bridge tops and lower string action heights, and will often have steel strings. Fiddle music is also taught by ear rather than by written music, because it's folk. This is the kind of fiddle music that came to Appalachia, and also other rural parts of early colonial America, where English settlers also played fiddle music.

National Socialism was not a conservative ideology.

>The first is that Hitler saw himself, accurately, as a revolutionary. Clearly it was a revolution of a different kind than that aimed at by Marxists, but it was still politics of a revolutionary kind and as such clearly distinct from the politics of the so-called bourgeois parties (liberals, social democrats, and Christian democrats) and also the conservatives and conventional nationalists. Zitelmann demonstrates that Hitler himself made this distinction, clearly and explicitly differentiating himself from the conservatives and putting the Nazi party, the Communists, and the Italian Fascists as rivals but fellow revolutionary movements, opposed to the constitutional politics of the bourgeois parties. He saw himself as a revolutionary because the political project he envisioned was one of fundamental transformation, a radical reshaping of the German social order, economy, and society. His politics was therefore total—encompassing every area of life, in the same way as communism—and he argued explicitly that this derived from its being a comprehensive weltanschauung (world view). This he explicitly contrasted to the limited and rule bound politics of liberalism and social and Christian democracy, which meant that it was conducted in a different way, one neither bound nor limited by law. The last aspect of this revolutionary approach was that the transformation of society it aimed at involved novelty and the creation of something new and unprecedented. This went along with a fascination, shared by most leading Nazis, with technology and modernism. This was all in marked contrast to the politics of radical reactionaries, such as the so-called conservative Maurras revolutionaries in Germany, and the Action Française in France, who looked to a reactionary politics of restoration and counter-revolution.

>During the 1956 peace talks between Japan and the Soviet Union, the Soviet side proposed to settle the dispute by returning Shikotan and Habomai to Japan. In the final round of the talks, the Japanese side accepted the weakness of its claim to Iturup and Kunashiri and agreed to settle on the return of Shikotan and the Habomai Islands, in exchange for a peace treaty. On October 19, 1956, in Moscow, the USSR and Japan signed the Soviet–Japanese Joint Declaration. The Declaration ended the state of war between the Soviet Union and Japan, which technically had still existed between the two countries since August 1945, and stipulated that "The U.S.S.R. and Japan have agreed to continue, after the establishment of normal diplomatic relations between them, negotiations for the conclusion of a peace treaty. Hereby, the U.S.S.R., in response to the desires of Japan and taking into consideration the interest of the Japanese state, agrees to hand over to Japan the Habomai and the Shikotan Islands, provided that the actual changing over to Japan of these islands will be carried out after the conclusion of a peace treaty.
>Continuation of the deadlock is often attributed to the United States' intervention in the negotiations, when US warned Japan that a withdrawal of the Japanese claim on the other islands would mean the U.S. would keep Okinawa and asserted that the San Francisco Peace Treaty "did not determine the sovereignty of the territories renounced by Japan", but that "Japan does not have the right to transfer sovereignty over such territories", although this attribution is problematic, since the decision to stand firm on demanding "four island return" (rather than following initial "minimal requirement" line of demanding only Shikotan and Habomai) was made by Japan long before the United States' decision to "morally support" these claims.

One of the ironies of 20th century communism is that the revolution took place in Russia, which was an extremely backwards country, and there was an expectation (and desperate hope) that the revolution would spread into Europe. But that failed and Stalin came to power and shifted to "socialism in one country" and reconciled socialism to the realities of a semi-Asiatic country going its own way, and that manifested as a political regime that was always a bit weird and exotic to Western communists.

But the revolution did spread anyways, it spread to China. So communism got a new boost of internationalist energy as a result of this, but it was a Stalinist-type of regime which was an adaptation to the failure of the revolution to spread (!), and in the opposite direction from the way it was "supposed" to go (!!). History is strange and contingent like that though. You could as a Marxist view it that way, and I think that's the way you're supposed to view it, capitalism itself came into being over a long period of time that was "inevitable" in a sense but also really corkscrewed, like it basically failed to come into being when it "should have" in the 17th century because the feudal superstructure was still too strong even though a lot of the manufacturing and trade to make capitalism take off already existed. And I think Stalin understood that, but the leaders who came after him didn't understand it.

Catechism of the Catholic Church:

246 The Latin tradition of the Creed confesses that the Spirit "proceeds from the Father and the Son (filioque)". the Council of Florence in 1438 explains: "The Holy Spirit is eternally from Father and Son; He has his nature and subsistence at once (simul) from the Father and the Son. He proceeds eternally from both as from one principle and through one spiration... And, since the Father has through generation given to the only-begotten Son everything that belongs to the Father, except being Father, the Son has also eternally from the Father, from whom he is eternally born, that the Holy Spirit proceeds from the Son."

248 At the outset the Eastern tradition expresses the Father's character as first origin of the Spirit. By confessing the Spirit as he "who proceeds from the Father", it affirms that he comes from the Father through the Son. The Western tradition expresses first the consubstantial communion between Father and Son, by saying that the Spirit proceeds from the Father and the Son (filioque). It says this, "legitimately and with good reason", for the eternal order of the divine persons in their consubstantial communion implies that the Father, as "the principle without principle", is the first origin of the Spirit, but also that as Father of the only Son, he is, with the Son, the single principle from which the Holy Spirit proceeds. This legitimate complementarity, provided it does not become rigid, does not affect the identity of faith in the reality of the same mystery confessed.

>Imagine what future we would have, had we kept the technological advanced from the late antiquity

Technology and innovation would have developed at a much slower pace if the Roman Empire never collapsed. We probably wouldn’t be as advanced as we are today

The reason europe was so advanced is because it was a ton of competing countries trying to beat each other in military, resource fathering, farming, colonisation etc. Which all needed more advanced tech. Necessity is the mother of invention, Britain, Spain and Portugal developed the best ships because they seriously needed them.

The romans literally had access and knowledge of a steam powered device and how it worked, and the only thing they did with it was use it as a fun toy. It could’ve easily been used to kick off industrialisation, but why bother? They had endless slaves to farm, no need to make a more efficient way to mow crops,

Same thing happened in China. They invented gun powder, and proceeded to pretty much only use it for fireworks. (There’s a handful of examples of attempts to make rockets to attack using it, but they quickly gave up and never tried to consistently use them)

Giant hegemonies stifle creation because they simply don’t need it to keep dominating.

In a more modern context, look at the space race. The invention and improvement of space flight, satellites etc moved at an incredible pace during the Cold War because of the competition between the USA and soviets, neither wanting the other to have an edge. When the soviets gave up on funding their space program. So did the Americans. By the time the USSR collapsed, space flight research had become very stagnant. It’s only really picked up once again when Spacex and other corporations began competing instead of countries doing so

>>14613460
Hitler wasn't completely unjustified in disagreeing with his generals. He was completely correct when attesting that they commonly ignored the economic realities of war, hence the focus of the likes of Halder on capturing Moscow rather than the resource-rich southern territories. He was also correct in prioritizing the Kiev pocket over allowing Guderian to continue driving towards Moscow. Leaving a massive concentration of Soviet troops behind the front was a recipe for disaster. Finally, it was Hitler's stand-fast orders that allowed the German Army to withstand the Moscow counteroffensive. Had he listened to his generals who wanted to retreat, something akin to a rout may have come about due to the lack of any real defensive lines to retreat to while valuable equipment would have to be abandoned.

He wasn't completely right in all things but the "madman Hitler" myth that Halder and others perpetuated was but an convenient excuse that allowed them to pass the blame for their own mistakes.

>On a sample of the Turin Shroud (TS), we applied a new method for dating ancient linen threads by inspecting their structural degradation by means of Wide-Angle X-ray Scattering (WAXS). The X-ray dating method was applied to a sample of the TS consisting of a thread taken in proximity of the 1988/radiocarbon area (corner of the TS corresponding to the feet area of the frontal image, near the so-called Raes sample). The size of the linen sample was about 0.5 mm × 1 mm. We obtained one-dimensional integrated WAXS data profiles for the TS sample, which were fully compatible with the analogous measurements obtained on a linen sample whose dating, according to historical records, is 55–74 AD, Siege of Masada (Israel). The degree of natural aging of the cellulose that constitutes the linen of the investigated sample, obtained by X-ray analysis, showed that the TS fabric is as old as the seven centuries proposed by the 1988 radiocarbon dating. The experimental results are compatible with the hypothesis that the TS is a 700-year-old relic, as opposed by Christian tradition, under the condition that it was kept at suitable levels of average secular temperature—20.0–22.5 °C—and correlated relative humidity—75–55%—for 7 centuries of history. To make the present result compatible with that of the 1988 radiocarbon test, the TS should have been conserved during its seven centuries of life at a secular room temperature very close to the maximum values registered on the earth.
This seems to debunk the Shroud of Turin, what do you guys think?

The Gospel of John tells us that Yeshua bar Yosef was buried in the traditional Jewish manner, with a shroud on his body, and another on his face. The Shroud of Turin, however, is a forgery created in the 14th century, by an illiterate painter. It makes sense that he wouldn't know the intricacies of Yeshua's burial, as he'd only ever heard of it in passing (if he'd heard of it at all, most Europeans were completely illiterate about basic Christian theology up until relatively recently). He would have been privy to the basic European custom of having a single cloth covering the body (as his work, the Shroud of Turin, is), and unless he was attending Jewish funerary rites, would never know that Jews, including Yeshua, according to John, are not shrouded in the same manner.

This tipped the local Bishop off when a painter was claiming to have found Jesus's burial shroud (the Bishop, unlike the painter, had actually read the Bible). He had the painter imprisoned, and the painter confessed to his crime. The Bishop asked the Pope what to do with the Shroud, and the Pope said to sell it for cash. The Bishop did, and the rest is history.

The Shroud of Turin can't be Yeshua's burial shroud, otherwise you open up the Bible to scrutiny such that the supposed witnesses (the disciples) can't be trusted to get basic facts of Yeshua's life and death wrong. For example, why would Yeshua be buried in the customs of a completely foreign people, yet this guy says that he was buried in the way that everyone else of Yeshua's race was?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14617865
>It looks tacky when I see American soldiers in the Gulf War wearing woodland vests over desert camo. Why did they do that?

You're probably thinking more of the Iraq War/GWOT

During Desert Storm, the standard issue US Military vest was the Kevlar-based PASGT, which was manufactured in M81 Woodland camouflage patterns, but there was also a Six Color Desert cover that could be worn over the standard vest. Most US troops in the Gulf War and later in Somalia were issued these overvests

During GWOT/Iraq however, the PASGT was in the process of being replaced by Interceptor Body Armor, which entered service in 1998. IBAs offered a significant improvement in protection over PASGT, such as being able to stop rifle-caliber bullets. However this came at the cost of making it a "hard vest", meaning that it had to use steel plates instead of Kevlar and was not as flexible. In addition, the traditional ALICE and LBV webbing systems were replaced by MOLLE, velcro inserts that allow you to directly attach things like pouches, radios, and. canteens directly to the vest. As a result, the IBA cannot be worn with an overvest of any kind

Where does camouflage come into this? Well, for the first three years of its production run, the vast majority of IBAs to roll off assembly lines were in Woodland camouflage, with the expectation of being used in Europe, South America, Asia, or Africa. After 9/11, production of IBAs in DCU pattern were increased dramatically, but they weren't able to filter through the US Army's supply system in time for the Iraq War. In the twilight years of BDUs (2004-2007), IBAs in DCU pattern finally started to be issued in large numbers and continued to see service until they were superseded by IOTVs (made in Universal Crap Pattern and later Multiscam)

This was a less of a problem for the US Marine Corps, which by 2001 was already planning on replacing camouflage vests for a single coyote brown one and large numbers were already in service by 2003.

posts.sub: How did a Wehrmacht armored division operate?
posts.com:
What kinds of vehicles did they use, just as a random marker, around the time of the Stalingrad campaign? Was it just tanks or were there infantry with them? If the latter is true, how did the infantry get around with the tanks? Did they coordinate with the Luftwaffe? How?

Also, and this is sort of off-topic for the rest of my questions. Why did everyone use bolt-actions while the Americans had m1-garands?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14619655
USA initially intended to use a rifle whose feedback mechanism was identical to the luger pistol. At the last moment, industrial espionage ruined the attempt and the garand was born. In any case, a luger-style mechanism would, though imho be easier to service,calso be more prone to environmental degradation. For industrial war, the garand was probably good enough.

At the same time, Germany had the beginnings of the assault rifle, which imho did not catch on also due to industrial greed and wehrmacht vs ss office politics.

I presume germany didn't start off with a garand-like weapon,cdespite clearly having the ability to produce one in mass, due to a of corruption, bad luck and the military industrial complex accidentally optimizing-away the prerequisites for a cheaper repeater like the garand.

For rtanks, look up interviews with Balcke (or Blacke¿), A famous German tank officer, who notes combined arms with air bombers was so perfect that on one occasion a town was hit with its last bomb detonating just in front of the first tank to enter it. On other occassions, the tankers were so comically ineffective as to ignore command to avoid roads, thereafter succombing to soviet ambush on the road. I inow little on this though, but i presume the combined arms precision required communication between the tankers themselves and the bombers over radio, lest friendly fire due to poor timing occur.

Wearing Revealing Clothing Isn’t Asserting Your Freedom

The reason I think this is simple.
When women wear less clothing, we are giving misogynists exactly what they want.
It serves misogynists for feminists to think that being scantily clad is an expression of freedom. It gives misogynists exactly what they want—consequence-free access to female bodies. They go to their other male friends and spread it, and on the cycle continues.
If getting naked were really the answer to gender relation problems, men would be doing it too. But we are not seeing a sudden popularity spike in the male crop-top, nor are we seeing any other kind of male-revealing clothing become popular.
Every year, women are wearing less and less clothing while men continue wearing the same amount of clothes as ever.
And look, I get it. When I go out, I feel the same pressure to be the sexiest bitch at the bar that every other woman does. My eyes rake over the most attractive women in public, measuring myself against them. (They didn’t start doing this until I started competing for male attention).
